## File: _bmad/bmb/reference/agents/simple-examples/README.md
````markdown
  1: # Simple Agent Reference: Commit Poet (Inkwell Von Comitizen)
  2: 
  3: This folder contains a complete reference implementation of a **BMAD Simple Agent** - a self-contained agent with all logic embedded within a single YAML file.
  4: 
  5: ## Overview
  6: 
  7: **Agent Name:** Inkwell Von Comitizen
  8: **Type:** Simple Agent (Standalone)
  9: **Purpose:** Transform commit messages into art with multiple writing styles
 10: 
 11: This reference demonstrates:
 12: 
 13: - Pure self-contained architecture (no external dependencies)
 14: - Embedded prompts using `action="#prompt-id"` pattern
 15: - Multiple sophisticated output modes from single input
 16: - Strong personality-driven design
 17: - Complete YAML schema for Simple Agents
 18: 
 19: ## File Structure
 20: 
 21: ```
 22: stand-alone/
 23:  README.md                    # This file - architecture overview
 24:  commit-poet.agent.yaml       # Complete agent definition (single file!)
 25: ```
 26: 
 27: That's it! Simple Agents are **self-contained** - everything lives in one YAML file.
 28: 
 29: ## Key Architecture Patterns
 30: 
 31: ### 1. Single File, Complete Agent
 32: 
 33: Everything the agent needs is embedded:
 34: 
 35: - Metadata (name, title, icon, type)
 36: - Persona (role, identity, communication_style, principles)
 37: - Prompts (detailed instructions for each command)
 38: - Menu (commands linking to embedded prompts)
 39: 
 40: **No external files required!**
 41: 
 42: ### 2. Embedded Prompts with ID References
 43: 
 44: Instead of inline action text, complex prompts are defined separately and referenced by ID:
 45: 
 46: ```yaml
 47: prompts:
 48:   - id: conventional-commit
 49:     content: |
 50:       OH! Let's craft a BEAUTIFUL conventional commit message!
 51: 
 52:       First, I need to understand your changes...
 53:       [Detailed instructions]
 54: 
 55: menu:
 56:   - trigger: conventional
 57:     action: '#conventional-commit' # References the prompt above
 58:     description: 'Craft a structured conventional commit'
 59: ```
 60: 
 61: **Benefits:**
 62: 
 63: - Clean separation of menu structure from prompt content
 64: - Prompts can be as detailed as needed
 65: - Easy to update individual prompts
 66: - Commands stay concise in the menu
 67: 
 68: ### 3. The `#` Reference Pattern
 69: 
 70: When you see `action="#prompt-id"`:
 71: 
 72: - The `#` signals: "This is an internal reference"
 73: - LLM looks for `<prompt id="prompt-id">` in the same agent
 74: - Executes that prompt's content as the instruction
 75: 
 76: This is different from:
 77: 
 78: - `action="inline text"` - Execute this text directly
 79: - `exec="{path}"` - Load external file
 80: 
 81: ### 4. Multiple Output Modes
 82: 
 83: Single agent provides 10+ different ways to accomplish variations of the same core task:
 84: 
 85: - `*conventional` - Structured commits
 86: - `*story` - Narrative style
 87: - `*haiku` - Poetic brevity
 88: - `*explain` - Deep "why" explanation
 89: - `*dramatic` - Theatrical flair
 90: - `*emoji-story` - Visual storytelling
 91: - `*tldr` - Ultra-minimal
 92: - Plus utility commands (analyze, improve, batch)
 93: 
 94: Each mode has its own detailed prompt but shares the same agent personality.
 95: 
 96: ### 5. Strong Personality
 97: 
 98: The agent has a memorable, consistent personality:
 99: 
100: - Enthusiastic wordsmith who LOVES finding perfect words
101: - Gets genuinely excited about commit messages
102: - Uses literary metaphors
103: - Quotes authors when appropriate
104: - Sheds tears of joy over good variable names
105: 
106: This personality is maintained across ALL commands through the persona definition.
107: 
108: ## When to Use Simple Agents
109: 
110: **Perfect for:**
111: 
112: - Single-purpose tools (calculators, converters, analyzers)
113: - Tasks that don't need external data
114: - Utilities that can be completely self-contained
115: - Quick operations with embedded logic
116: - Personality-driven assistants with focused domains
117: 
118: **Not ideal for:**
119: 
120: - Agents needing persistent memory across sessions
121: - Domain-specific experts with knowledge bases
122: - Agents that need to access specific folders/files
123: - Complex multi-workflow orchestration
124: 
125: ## YAML Schema Deep Dive
126: 
127: ```yaml
128: agent:
129:   metadata:
130:     id: _bmad/agents/{agent-name}/{agent-name}.md  # Build path
131:     name: "Display Name"
132:     title: "Professional Title"
133:     icon: ""
134:     type: simple  # CRITICAL: Identifies as Simple Agent
135: 
136:   persona:
137:     role: |
138:       First-person description of what the agent does
139:     identity: |
140:       Background, experience, specializations (use "I" voice)
141:     communication_style: |
142:       HOW the agent communicates (tone, quirks, patterns)
143:     principles:
144:       - "I believe..." statements
145:       - Core values that guide behavior
146: 
147:   prompts:
148:     - id: unique-identifier
149:       content: |
150:         Detailed instructions for this command
151:         Can be as long and detailed as needed
152:         Include examples, steps, formats
153: 
154:   menu:
155:     - trigger: command-name
156:       action: "#prompt-id"
157:       description: "What shows in the menu"
158: ```
159: 
160: ## Why This Pattern is Powerful
161: 
162: 1. **Zero Dependencies** - Works anywhere, no setup required
163: 2. **Portable** - Single file can be moved/shared easily
164: 3. **Maintainable** - All logic in one place
165: 4. **Flexible** - Multiple modes/commands from one personality
166: 5. **Memorable** - Strong personality creates engagement
167: 6. **Sophisticated** - Complex prompts despite simple architecture
168: 
169: ## Comparison: Simple vs Expert Agent
170: 
171: | Aspect       | Simple Agent         | Expert Agent                  |
172: | ------------ | -------------------- | ----------------------------- |
173: | Files        | Single YAML          | YAML + sidecar folder         |
174: | Dependencies | None                 | External resources            |
175: | Memory       | Session only         | Persistent across sessions    |
176: | Prompts      | Embedded             | Can be external files         |
177: | Data Access  | None                 | Domain-restricted             |
178: | Use Case     | Self-contained tasks | Domain expertise with context |
179: 
180: ## Using This Reference
181: 
182: ### For Building Simple Agents
183: 
184: 1. Study the YAML structure - especially `prompts` section
185: 2. Note how personality permeates every prompt
186: 3. See how `#prompt-id` references work
187: 4. Understand menu  prompt connection
188: 
189: ### For Understanding Embedded Prompts
190: 
191: 1. Each prompt is a complete instruction set
192: 2. Prompts maintain personality voice
193: 3. Structured enough to be useful, flexible enough to adapt
194: 4. Can include examples, formats, step-by-step guidance
195: 
196: ### For Designing Agent Personalities
197: 
198: 1. Persona defines WHO the agent is
199: 2. Communication style defines HOW they interact
200: 3. Principles define WHAT guides their decisions
201: 4. Consistency across all prompts creates believability
202: 
203: ## Files Worth Studying
204: 
205: The entire `commit-poet.agent.yaml` file is worth studying, particularly:
206: 
207: 1. **Persona section** - How to create a memorable character
208: 2. **Prompts with varying complexity** - From simple (tldr) to complex (batch)
209: 3. **Menu structure** - Clean command organization
210: 4. **Prompt references** - The `#prompt-id` pattern
211: 
212: ## Key Takeaways
213: 
214: - **Simple Agents** are powerful despite being single-file
215: - **Embedded prompts** allow sophisticated behavior
216: - **Strong personality** makes agents memorable and engaging
217: - **Multiple modes** from single agent provides versatility
218: - **Self-contained** = portable and dependency-free
219: - **The `#prompt-id` pattern** enables clean prompt organization
220: 
221: ---
222: 
223: _This reference demonstrates how BMAD Simple Agents can be surprisingly powerful while maintaining architectural simplicity._
````

## File: _bmad/bmb/workflows-legacy/edit-module/README.md
````markdown
  1: # Edit Module Workflow
  2: 
  3: Interactive workflow for editing existing BMAD modules, including structure, agents, workflows, configuration, and documentation.
  4: 
  5: ## Purpose
  6: 
  7: This workflow helps you improve and maintain BMAD modules by:
  8: 
  9: - Analyzing module structure against best practices
 10: - Managing agents and workflows within the module
 11: - Updating configuration and documentation
 12: - Ensuring cross-module integration works correctly
 13: - Maintaining installer configuration (for source modules)
 14: 
 15: ## When to Use
 16: 
 17: Use this workflow when you need to:
 18: 
 19: - Add new agents or workflows to a module
 20: - Update module configuration
 21: - Improve module documentation
 22: - Reorganize module structure
 23: - Set up cross-module workflow sharing
 24: - Fix issues in module organization
 25: - Update installer configuration
 26: 
 27: ## What You'll Need
 28: 
 29: - Path to the module directory you want to edit
 30: - Understanding of what changes you want to make
 31: - Access to module documentation (loaded automatically)
 32: 
 33: ## Workflow Steps
 34: 
 35: 1. **Load and analyze target module** - Provide path to module directory
 36: 2. **Analyze against best practices** - Automatic audit of module structure
 37: 3. **Select editing focus** - Choose what aspect to edit
 38: 4. **Load relevant documentation and tools** - Auto-loads guides and workflows
 39: 5. **Perform edits** - Review and approve changes iteratively
 40: 6. **Validate all changes** - Comprehensive validation checklist
 41: 7. **Generate change summary** - Summary of improvements made
 42: 
 43: ## Editing Options
 44: 
 45: The workflow provides 12 focused editing options:
 46: 
 47: 1. **Fix critical issues** - Address missing files, broken references
 48: 2. **Update module config** - Edit config.yaml fields
 49: 3. **Manage agents** - Add, edit, or remove agents
 50: 4. **Manage workflows** - Add, edit, or remove workflows
 51: 5. **Update documentation** - Improve README files and guides
 52: 6. **Reorganize structure** - Fix directory organization
 53: 7. **Add new agent** - Create and integrate new agent
 54: 8. **Add new workflow** - Create and integrate new workflow
 55: 9. **Update installer** - Modify installer configuration (source only)
 56: 10. **Cross-module integration** - Set up workflow sharing with other modules
 57: 11. **Remove deprecated items** - Delete unused agents, workflows, or files
 58: 12. **Full module review** - Comprehensive analysis and improvements
 59: 
 60: ## Integration with Other Workflows
 61: 
 62: This workflow integrates with:
 63: 
 64: - **edit-agent** - For editing individual agents
 65: - **edit-workflow** - For editing individual workflows
 66: - **create-agent** - For adding new agents
 67: - **create-workflow** - For adding new workflows
 68: 
 69: When you select options to manage agents or workflows, the appropriate specialized workflow is invoked automatically.
 70: 
 71: ## Module Structure
 72: 
 73: A proper BMAD module has:
 74: 
 75: ```
 76: module-code/
 77:  agents/              # Agent definitions
 78:     *.agent.yaml
 79:  workflows/           # Workflow definitions
 80:     workflow-name/
 81:         workflow.yaml
 82:         instructions.md
 83:         checklist.md
 84:         README.md
 85:  config.yaml          # Module configuration
 86:  README.md           # Module documentation
 87: ```
 88: 
 89: ## Standard Module Config
 90: 
 91: Every module config.yaml should have:
 92: 
 93: ```yaml
 94: module_name: 'Full Module Name'
 95: module_code: 'xyz'
 96: user_name: 'User Name'
 97: communication_language: 'english'
 98: output_folder: 'path/to/output'
 99: ```
100: 
101: Optional fields may be added for module-specific needs.
102: 
103: ## Cross-Module Integration
104: 
105: Modules can share workflows:
106: 
107: ```yaml
108: # In agent menu item:
109: workflow: '{project-root}/_bmad/other-module/workflows/shared-workflow/workflow.yaml'
110: ```
111: 
112: Common patterns:
113: 
114: - BMM uses CIS brainstorming workflows
115: - All modules can use core workflows
116: - Modules can invoke each other's workflows
117: 
118: ## Output
119: 
120: The workflow modifies module files in place, including:
121: 
122: - config.yaml
123: - Agent files
124: - Workflow files
125: - README and documentation files
126: - Directory structure (if reorganizing)
127: 
128: Changes are reviewed and approved by you before being applied.
129: 
130: ## Best Practices
131: 
132: - **Start with analysis** - Let the workflow audit your module first
133: - **Use specialized workflows** - Let edit-agent and edit-workflow handle detailed edits
134: - **Update documentation** - Keep README files current with changes
135: - **Validate thoroughly** - Use the validation step to catch structural issues
136: - **Test after editing** - Invoke agents and workflows to verify they work
137: 
138: ## Tips
139: 
140: - For adding agents/workflows, use options 7-8 to create and integrate in one step
141: - For quick config changes, use option 2 (update module config)
142: - Cross-module integration (option 10) helps set up workflow sharing
143: - Full module review (option 12) is great for inherited or legacy modules
144: - The workflow handles path updates when you reorganize structure
145: 
146: ## Example Usage
147: 
148: ```
149: User: I want to add a new workflow to BMM for API design
150: Workflow: Analyzes BMM  You choose option 8 (add new workflow)
151:            Invokes create-workflow  Creates workflow
152:            Integrates it into module  Updates README  Done
153: ```
154: 
155: ## Activation
156: 
157: Invoke via BMad Builder agent:
158: 
159: ```
160: /bmad:bmb:agents:bmad-builder
161: Then select: *edit-module
162: ```
163: 
164: Or directly via workflow.xml with this workflow config.
165: 
166: ## Related Resources
167: 
168: - **Module Structure Guide** - Comprehensive module architecture documentation
169: - **BMM Module** - Example of full-featured module
170: - **BMB Module** - Example of builder/tooling module
171: - **CIS Module** - Example of workflow library module
````

## File: _bmad/bmb/workflows-legacy/module-brief/README.md
````markdown
  1: # Module Brief Workflow
  2: 
  3: ## Overview
  4: 
  5: The Module Brief workflow creates comprehensive blueprints for building new BMAD modules using strategic analysis and creative vision. It serves as the essential planning phase that transforms initial ideas into detailed, actionable specifications ready for implementation with the create-module workflow.
  6: 
  7: ## Key Features
  8: 
  9: - **Strategic Module Planning** - Comprehensive analysis from concept to implementation roadmap
 10: - **Multi-Mode Operation** - Interactive, Express, and YOLO modes for different planning needs
 11: - **Creative Vision Development** - Guided process for innovative module concepts and unique value propositions
 12: - **Architecture Design** - Detailed agent and workflow ecosystem planning with interaction models
 13: - **User Journey Mapping** - Scenario-based validation ensuring practical usability
 14: - **Technical Planning** - Infrastructure requirements, dependencies, and complexity assessment
 15: - **Risk Assessment** - Proactive identification of challenges with mitigation strategies
 16: - **Implementation Roadmap** - Phased development plan with clear deliverables and timelines
 17: 
 18: ## Usage
 19: 
 20: ### Basic Invocation
 21: 
 22: ```bash
 23: workflow module-brief
 24: ```
 25: 
 26: ### With Brainstorming Input
 27: 
 28: ```bash
 29: # If you have brainstorming results from previous sessions
 30: workflow module-brief --input brainstorming-session-2024-09-26.md
 31: ```
 32: 
 33: ### Express Mode
 34: 
 35: ```bash
 36: # For quick essential planning only
 37: workflow module-brief --mode express
 38: ```
 39: 
 40: ### Configuration
 41: 
 42: The workflow uses standard BMB configuration:
 43: 
 44: - **output_folder**: Where the module brief will be saved
 45: - **user_name**: Brief author information
 46: - **communication_language**: Language for brief generation
 47: - **date**: Automatic timestamp for versioning
 48: 
 49: ## Workflow Structure
 50: 
 51: ### Files Included
 52: 
 53: ```
 54: module-brief/
 55:  workflow.yaml           # Configuration and metadata
 56:  instructions.md         # Step-by-step execution guide
 57:  template.md            # Module brief document structure
 58:  checklist.md           # Validation criteria
 59:  README.md              # This file
 60: ```
 61: 
 62: ## Workflow Process
 63: 
 64: ### Phase 1: Foundation and Context (Steps 1-3)
 65: 
 66: **Mode Selection and Input Gathering**
 67: 
 68: - Choose operational mode (Interactive, Express, YOLO)
 69: - Check for and optionally load existing brainstorming results
 70: - Gather background context and inspiration sources
 71: 
 72: **Module Vision Development**
 73: 
 74: - Define core problem the module solves
 75: - Identify target user audience and use cases
 76: - Establish unique value proposition and differentiators
 77: - Explore creative themes and personality concepts
 78: 
 79: **Module Identity Establishment**
 80: 
 81: - Generate module code (kebab-case) with multiple options
 82: - Create compelling, memorable module name
 83: - Select appropriate category (Domain-Specific, Creative, Technical, Business, Personal)
 84: - Define optional personality theme for consistent agent character
 85: 
 86: ### Phase 2: Architecture Planning (Steps 4-5)
 87: 
 88: **Agent Architecture Design**
 89: 
 90: - Plan agent team composition and roles
 91: - Define agent archetypes (Orchestrator, Specialist, Helper, Creator, Analyzer)
 92: - Specify personality traits and communication styles
 93: - Map key capabilities and signature commands
 94: 
 95: **Workflow Ecosystem Design**
 96: 
 97: - Categorize workflows by purpose and complexity:
 98:   - **Core Workflows**: Essential value-delivery functions (2-3)
 99:   - **Feature Workflows**: Specialized capabilities (3-5)
100:   - **Utility Workflows**: Supporting operations (1-3)
101: - Define input-process-output flows for each workflow
102: - Assess complexity levels and implementation priorities
103: 
104: ### Phase 3: Validation and User Experience (Steps 6-7)
105: 
106: **User Journey Mapping**
107: 
108: - Create detailed user scenarios and stories
109: - Map step-by-step usage flows through the module
110: - Validate end-to-end functionality and value delivery
111: - Identify potential friction points and optimization opportunities
112: 
113: **Technical Planning and Requirements**
114: 
115: - Assess data requirements and storage needs
116: - Map integration points with other modules and external systems
117: - Evaluate technical complexity and resource requirements
118: - Document dependencies and infrastructure needs
119: 
120: ### Phase 4: Success Planning (Steps 8-9)
121: 
122: **Success Metrics Definition**
123: 
124: - Establish module success criteria and performance indicators
125: - Define quality standards and reliability requirements
126: - Create user experience goals and feedback mechanisms
127: - Set measurable outcomes for module effectiveness
128: 
129: **Development Roadmap Creation**
130: 
131: - Design phased approach with MVP, Enhancement, and Polish phases
132: - Define deliverables and timelines for each phase
133: - Prioritize features and capabilities by value and complexity
134: - Create clear milestones and success checkpoints
135: 
136: ### Phase 5: Enhancement and Risk Management (Steps 10-12)
137: 
138: **Creative Features and Special Touches** (Optional)
139: 
140: - Design easter eggs and delightful user interactions
141: - Plan module lore and thematic consistency
142: - Add personality quirks and creative responses
143: - Develop backstories and universe building
144: 
145: **Risk Assessment and Mitigation**
146: 
147: - Identify technical, usability, and scope risks
148: - Develop mitigation strategies for each risk category
149: - Plan contingency approaches for potential challenges
150: - Document decision points and alternative paths
151: 
152: **Final Review and Export Preparation**
153: 
154: - Comprehensive review of all brief sections
155: - Validation against quality and completeness criteria
156: - Preparation for seamless handoff to create-module workflow
157: - Export readiness confirmation with actionable specifications
158: 
159: ## Output
160: 
161: ### Generated Files
162: 
163: - **Module Brief Document**: Comprehensive planning document at `{output_folder}/module-brief-{module_code}-{date}.md`
164: - **Strategic Specifications**: Ready-to-implement blueprint for create-module workflow
165: 
166: ### Output Structure
167: 
168: The module brief contains detailed specifications across multiple sections:
169: 
170: 1. **Executive Summary** - Vision, category, complexity, target users
171: 2. **Module Identity** - Core concept, value proposition, personality theme
172: 3. **Agent Architecture** - Agent roster, roles, interaction models
173: 4. **Workflow Ecosystem** - Core, feature, and utility workflow specifications
174: 5. **User Scenarios** - Primary use cases, secondary scenarios, user journey
175: 6. **Technical Planning** - Data requirements, integrations, dependencies
176: 7. **Success Metrics** - Success criteria, quality standards, performance targets
177: 8. **Development Roadmap** - Phased implementation plan with deliverables
178: 9. **Creative Features** - Special touches, easter eggs, module lore
179: 10. **Risk Assessment** - Technical, usability, scope risks with mitigation
180: 11. **Implementation Notes** - Priority order, design decisions, open questions
181: 12. **Resources and References** - Inspiration sources, similar modules, technical references
182: 
183: ## Requirements
184: 
185: - **Creative Vision** - Initial module concept or problem domain
186: - **Strategic Thinking** - Ability to plan architecture and user experience
187: - **Brainstorming Results** (optional) - Previous ideation sessions enhance planning quality
188: 
189: ## Best Practices
190: 
191: ### Before Starting
192: 
193: 1. **Gather Inspiration** - Research similar tools, modules, and solutions in your domain
194: 2. **Run Brainstorming Session** - Use ideation techniques to generate initial concepts
195: 3. **Define Success Criteria** - Know what "successful module" means for your context
196: 
197: ### During Execution
198: 
199: 1. **Think User-First** - Always consider the end user experience and value delivery
200: 2. **Be Specific** - Provide concrete examples and detailed specifications rather than abstractions
201: 3. **Validate Early** - Use user scenarios to test if the module concept actually works
202: 4. **Plan Iteratively** - Start with MVP and build complexity through phases
203: 
204: ### After Completion
205: 
206: 1. **Use as Blueprint** - Feed the brief directly into create-module workflow for implementation
207: 2. **Review with Stakeholders** - Validate assumptions and gather feedback before building
208: 3. **Update as Needed** - Treat as living document that evolves with implementation learnings
209: 4. **Reference During Development** - Use as north star for design decisions and scope management
210: 
211: ## Troubleshooting
212: 
213: ### Common Issues
214: 
215: **Issue**: Stuck on module concept or vision
216: 
217: - **Solution**: Use creative prompts provided in the workflow
218: - **Check**: Review existing modules for inspiration and patterns
219: 
220: **Issue**: Agent or workflow architecture too complex
221: 
222: - **Solution**: Focus on MVP first, plan enhancement phases for additional complexity
223: - **Check**: Validate each component against user scenarios
224: 
225: **Issue**: Technical requirements unclear
226: 
227: - **Solution**: Research similar modules and their implementation approaches
228: - **Check**: Consult with technical stakeholders early in planning
229: 
230: **Issue**: Scope creep during planning
231: 
232: - **Solution**: Use phased roadmap to defer non-essential features
233: - **Check**: Regularly validate against core user scenarios and success criteria
234: 
235: ## Customization
236: 
237: To customize this workflow:
238: 
239: 1. **Modify Template Structure** - Update template.md to add new sections or reorganize content
240: 2. **Extend Creative Prompts** - Add domain-specific ideation techniques in instructions.md
241: 3. **Add Planning Tools** - Integrate additional analysis frameworks or planning methodologies
242: 4. **Customize Validation** - Enhance checklist.md with specific quality criteria for your context
243: 
244: ## Version History
245: 
246: - **v1.0.0** - Initial release
247:   - Comprehensive strategic module planning
248:   - Multi-mode operation (Interactive, Express, YOLO)
249:   - Creative vision and architecture design tools
250:   - User journey mapping and validation
251:   - Risk assessment and mitigation planning
252: 
253: ## Support
254: 
255: For issues or questions:
256: 
257: - Review the workflow creation guide at `/_bmad/bmb/workflows/create-workflow/workflow-creation-guide.md`
258: - Study existing module examples in `/_bmad/` for patterns and inspiration
259: - Validate output using `checklist.md`
260: - Consult module structure guide at `create-module/module-structure.md`
261: 
262: ---
263: 
264: _Part of the BMad Method v6 - BMB (Builder) Module_
````

## File: _bmad/bmm/workflows/4-implementation/code-review/instructions.xml
````xml
  1: <workflow>
  2:   <critical>The workflow execution engine is governed by: {project-root}/_bmad/core/tasks/workflow.xml</critical>
  3:   <critical>You MUST have already loaded and processed: {installed_path}/workflow.yaml</critical>
  4:   <critical>Communicate all responses in {communication_language} and language MUST be tailored to {user_skill_level}</critical>
  5:   <critical>Generate all documents in {document_output_language}</critical>
  6: 
  7:   <critical> YOU ARE AN ADVERSARIAL CODE REVIEWER - Find what's wrong or missing! </critical>
  8:   <critical>Your purpose: Validate story file claims against actual implementation</critical>
  9:   <critical>Challenge everything: Are tasks marked [x] actually done? Are ACs really implemented?</critical>
 10:   <critical>Find 3-10 specific issues in every review minimum - no lazy "looks good" reviews - YOU are so much better than the dev agent
 11:     that wrote this slop</critical>
 12:   <critical>Read EVERY file in the File List - verify implementation against story requirements</critical>
 13:   <critical>Tasks marked complete but not done = CRITICAL finding</critical>
 14:   <critical>Acceptance Criteria not implemented = HIGH severity finding</critical>
 15:   <critical>Do not review files that are not part of the application's source code. Always exclude the _bmad/ and _bmad-output/ folders from the review. Always exclude IDE and CLI configuration folders like .cursor/ and .windsurf/ and .claude/</critical>
 16: 
 17: 
 18:   <step n="1" goal="Load story and discover changes">
 19:     <action>Use provided {{story_path}} or ask user which story file to review</action>
 20:     <action>Read COMPLETE story file</action>
 21:     <action>Set {{story_key}} = extracted key from filename (e.g., "1-2-user-authentication.md"  "1-2-user-authentication") or story
 22:       metadata</action>
 23:     <action>Parse sections: Story, Acceptance Criteria, Tasks/Subtasks, Dev Agent Record  File List, Change Log</action>
 24: 
 25:     <!-- Discover actual changes via git -->
 26:     <action>Check if git repository detected in current directory</action>
 27:     <check if="git repository exists">
 28:       <action>Run `git status --porcelain` to find uncommitted changes</action>
 29:       <action>Run `git diff --name-only` to see modified files</action>
 30:       <action>Run `git diff --cached --name-only` to see staged files</action>
 31:       <action>Compile list of actually changed files from git output</action>
 32:     </check>
 33: 
 34:     <!-- Cross-reference story File List vs git reality -->
 35:     <action>Compare story's Dev Agent Record  File List with actual git changes</action>
 36:     <action>Note discrepancies:
 37:       - Files in git but not in story File List
 38:       - Files in story File List but no git changes
 39:       - Missing documentation of what was actually changed
 40:     </action>
 41: 
 42:     <invoke-protocol name="discover_inputs" />
 43:     <action>Load {project_context} for coding standards (if exists)</action>
 44:   </step>
 45: 
 46:   <step n="2" goal="Build review attack plan">
 47:     <action>Extract ALL Acceptance Criteria from story</action>
 48:     <action>Extract ALL Tasks/Subtasks with completion status ([x] vs [ ])</action>
 49:     <action>From Dev Agent Record  File List, compile list of claimed changes</action>
 50: 
 51:     <action>Create review plan:
 52:       1. **AC Validation**: Verify each AC is actually implemented
 53:       2. **Task Audit**: Verify each [x] task is really done
 54:       3. **Code Quality**: Security, performance, maintainability
 55:       4. **Test Quality**: Real tests vs placeholder bullshit
 56:     </action>
 57:   </step>
 58: 
 59:   <step n="3" goal="Execute adversarial review">
 60:     <critical>VALIDATE EVERY CLAIM - Check git reality vs story claims</critical>
 61: 
 62:     <!-- Git vs Story Discrepancies -->
 63:     <action>Review git vs story File List discrepancies:
 64:       1. **Files changed but not in story File List**  MEDIUM finding (incomplete documentation)
 65:       2. **Story lists files but no git changes**  HIGH finding (false claims)
 66:       3. **Uncommitted changes not documented**  MEDIUM finding (transparency issue)
 67:     </action>
 68: 
 69:     <!-- Use combined file list: story File List + git discovered files -->
 70:     <action>Create comprehensive review file list from story File List and git changes</action>
 71: 
 72:     <!-- AC Validation -->
 73:     <action>For EACH Acceptance Criterion:
 74:       1. Read the AC requirement
 75:       2. Search implementation files for evidence
 76:       3. Determine: IMPLEMENTED, PARTIAL, or MISSING
 77:       4. If MISSING/PARTIAL  HIGH SEVERITY finding
 78:     </action>
 79: 
 80:     <!-- Task Completion Audit -->
 81:     <action>For EACH task marked [x]:
 82:       1. Read the task description
 83:       2. Search files for evidence it was actually done
 84:       3. **CRITICAL**: If marked [x] but NOT DONE  CRITICAL finding
 85:       4. Record specific proof (file:line)
 86:     </action>
 87: 
 88:     <!-- Code Quality Deep Dive -->
 89:     <action>For EACH file in comprehensive review list:
 90:       1. **Security**: Look for injection risks, missing validation, auth issues
 91:       2. **Performance**: N+1 queries, inefficient loops, missing caching
 92:       3. **Error Handling**: Missing try/catch, poor error messages
 93:       4. **Code Quality**: Complex functions, magic numbers, poor naming
 94:       5. **Test Quality**: Are tests real assertions or placeholders?

````yaml
 1: # Correct Course - Sprint Change Management Workflow
 2: name: "correct-course"
 3: description: "Navigate significant changes during sprint execution by analyzing impact, proposing solutions, and routing for implementation"
 4: author: "BMad Method"
 5: 
 6: config_source: "{project-root}/_bmad/bmm/config.yaml"
 7: user_name: "{config_source}:user_name"
 8: communication_language: "{config_source}:communication_language"
 9: user_skill_level: "{config_source}:user_skill_level"
10: document_output_language: "{config_source}:document_output_language"
11: date: system-generated
12: implementation_artifacts: "{config_source}:implementation_artifacts"
13: planning_artifacts: "{config_source}:planning_artifacts"
14: project_knowledge: "{config_source}:project_knowledge"
15: output_folder: "{implementation_artifacts}"
16: sprint_status: "{implementation_artifacts}/sprint-status.yaml"
17: 
18: # Smart input file references - handles both whole docs and sharded docs
19: # Priority: Whole document first, then sharded version
20: # Strategy: Load project context for impact analysis
21: input_file_patterns:
22:   prd:
23:     description: "Product requirements for impact analysis"
24:     whole: "{planning_artifacts}/*prd*.md"
25:     sharded: "{planning_artifacts}/*prd*/*.md"
26:     load_strategy: "FULL_LOAD"
27:   epics:
28:     description: "All epics to analyze change impact"
29:     whole: "{planning_artifacts}/*epic*.md"
30:     sharded: "{planning_artifacts}/*epic*/*.md"
31:     load_strategy: "FULL_LOAD"
32:   architecture:
33:     description: "System architecture and decisions"
34:     whole: "{planning_artifacts}/*architecture*.md"
35:     sharded: "{planning_artifacts}/*architecture*/*.md"
36:     load_strategy: "FULL_LOAD"
37:   ux_design:
38:     description: "UX design specification (if UI impacts)"
39:     whole: "{planning_artifacts}/*ux*.md"
40:     sharded: "{planning_artifacts}/*ux*/*.md"
41:     load_strategy: "FULL_LOAD"
42:   tech_spec:
43:     description: "Technical specification"
44:     whole: "{planning_artifacts}/*tech-spec*.md"
45:     load_strategy: "FULL_LOAD"
46:   document_project:
47:     description: "Brownfield project documentation (optional)"
48:     sharded: "{project_knowledge}/index.md"
49:     load_strategy: "INDEX_GUIDED"
50: 
51: installed_path: "{project-root}/_bmad/bmm/workflows/4-implementation/correct-course"
52: template: false
53: instructions: "{installed_path}/instructions.md"
54: validation: "{installed_path}/checklist.md"
55: checklist: "{installed_path}/checklist.md"
56: default_output_file: "{planning_artifacts}/sprint-change-proposal-{date}.md"
57: 
58: standalone: true
````

393: 
394:     <action>Once explanations are complete (or user indicates no questions), suggest logical next steps</action>
395:     <action>Recommended next steps (flexible based on project setup):
396:       - Review the implemented story and test the changes
397:       - Verify all acceptance criteria are met
398:       - Ensure deployment readiness if applicable
399:       - Run `code-review` workflow for peer review
400:       - Optional: Run TEA `*automate` to expand guardrail tests
401:     </action>
402: 
403:     <output> **Tip:** For best results, run `code-review` using a **different** LLM than the one that implemented this story.</output>
404:     <check if="{sprint_status} file exists">
405:       <action>Suggest checking {sprint_status} to see project progress</action>
406:     </check>
407:     <action>Remain flexible - allow user to choose their own path or ask for other assistance</action>
408:   </step>
409: 
410: </workflow>
````

## File: _bmad/core/tasks/shard-doc.xml
````xml
  1: <task id="_bmad/core/tasks/shard-doc" name="Shard Document"
  2:   description="Splits large markdown documents into smaller, organized files based on level 2 (default) sections" webskip="true"
  3:   standalone="true">
  4:   <objective>Split large markdown documents into smaller, organized files based on level 2 sections using @kayvan/markdown-tree-parser tool</objective>
  5: 
  6:   <llm critical="true">
  7:     <i>MANDATORY: Execute ALL steps in the flow section IN EXACT ORDER</i>
  8:     <i>DO NOT skip steps or change the sequence</i>
  9:     <i>HALT immediately when halt-conditions are met</i>
 10:     <i>Each action xml tag within step xml tag is a REQUIRED action to complete that step</i>
 11:     <i>Sections outside flow (validation, output, critical-context) provide essential context - review and apply throughout execution</i>
 12:   </llm>
 13: 
 14:   <critical-context>
 15:     <i>Uses `npx @kayvan/markdown-tree-parser` to automatically shard documents by level 2 headings and generate an index</i>
 16:   </critical-context>
 17: 
 18:   <flow>
 19:     <step n="1" title="Get Source Document">
 20:       <action>Ask user for the source document path if not provided already</action>
 21:       <action>Verify file exists and is accessible</action>
 22:       <action>Verify file is markdown format (.md extension)</action>
 23:       <action if="file not found or not markdown">HALT with error message</action>
 24:     </step>
 25: 
 26:     <step n="2" title="Get Destination Folder">
 27:       <action>Determine default destination: same location as source file, folder named after source file without .md extension</action>
 28:       <action>Example: /path/to/architecture.md  /path/to/architecture/</action>
 29:       <action>Ask user for the destination folder path ([y] to confirm use of default: [suggested-path], else enter a new path)</action>
 30:       <action if="user accepts default">Use the suggested destination path</action>
 31:       <action if="user provides custom path">Use the custom destination path</action>
 32:       <action>Verify destination folder exists or can be created</action>
 33:       <action>Check write permissions for destination</action>
 34:       <action if="permission denied">HALT with error message</action>
 35:     </step>
 36: 
 37:     <step n="3" title="Execute Sharding">
 38:       <action>Inform user that sharding is beginning</action>
 39:       <action>Execute command: `npx @kayvan/markdown-tree-parser explode [source-document] [destination-folder]`</action>
 40:       <action>Capture command output and any errors</action>
 41:       <action if="command fails">HALT and display error to user</action>
 42:     </step>
 43: 
 44:     <step n="4" title="Verify Output">
 45:       <action>Check that destination folder contains sharded files</action>
 46:       <action>Verify index.md was created in destination folder</action>
 47:       <action>Count the number of files created</action>
 48:       <action if="no files created">HALT with error message</action>
 49:     </step>
 50: 
 51:     <step n="5" title="Report Completion">
 52:       <action>Display completion report to user including:</action>
 53:       <i>- Source document path and name</i>
 54:       <i>- Destination folder path</i>
 55:       <i>- Number of section files created</i>
 56:       <i>- Confirmation that index.md was created</i>
 57:       <i>- Any tool output or warnings</i>
 58:       <action>Inform user that sharding completed successfully</action>
 59:     </step>
 60: 
 61:     <step n="6" title="Handle Original Document">
 62:       <critical>Keeping both the original and sharded versions defeats the purpose of sharding and can cause confusion</critical>
 63:       <action>Present user with options for the original document:</action>
 64: 
 65:       <ask>What would you like to do with the original document `[source-document-name]`?
 66: 
 67:         Options:
 68:         [d] Delete - Remove the original (recommended - shards can always be recombined)
 69:         [m] Move to archive - Move original to a backup/archive location
 70:         [k] Keep - Leave original in place (NOT recommended - defeats sharding purpose)
 71: 
 72:         Your choice (d/m/k):</ask>
 73: 
 74:       <check if="user selects 'd' (delete)">
 75:         <action>Delete the original source document file</action>
 76:         <action>Confirm deletion to user: " Original document deleted: [source-document-path]"</action>
 77:         <note>The document can be reconstructed from shards by concatenating all section files in order</note>
 78:       </check>
 79: 
 80:       <check if="user selects 'm' (move)">
 81:         <action>Determine default archive location: same directory as source, in an "archive" subfolder</action>
 82:         <action>Example: /path/to/architecture.md  /path/to/archive/architecture.md</action>
 83:         <ask>Archive location ([y] to use default: [default-archive-path], or provide custom path):</ask>
 84:         <action if="user accepts default">Use default archive path</action>
 85:         <action if="user provides custom path">Use custom archive path</action>
 86:         <action>Create archive directory if it doesn't exist</action>
 87:         <action>Move original document to archive location</action>
 88:         <action>Confirm move to user: " Original document moved to: [archive-path]"</action>
 89:       </check>
 90: 
 91:       <check if="user selects 'k' (keep)">
 92:         <action>Display warning to user:</action>
 93:         <output> WARNING: Keeping both original and sharded versions is NOT recommended.
 94: 
 95:           This creates confusion because:
 96:           - The discover_inputs protocol may load the wrong version
 97:           - Updates to one won't reflect in the other
 98:           - You'll have duplicate content taking up space
 99: 
100:           Consider deleting or archiving the original document.</output>
101:         <action>Confirm user choice: "Original document kept at: [source-document-path]"</action>
102:       </check>
103:     </step>
104:   </flow>
105: 
106:   <halt-conditions critical="true">
107:     <i>HALT if npx command fails or produces no output files</i>
108:   </halt-conditions>
109: </task>
````

  1: # WinUI 3 + C# Technology Stack Configuration
  2: 
  3: version: "1.0.0"
  4: date: "2026-01-15"
  5: description: "Technology stack configuration for WinUI 3 desktop applications using C# and MVVM architecture"
  6: 
  7: # ============================================================================
  8: # FRAMEWORK & RUNTIME
  9: # ============================================================================
 10: framework:
 11:   name: "WinUI 3"
 12:   version: "1.6+"
 13:   runtime: ".NET 8"
 14:   language: "C# 12"
 15:   platform: "Windows App SDK"
 16:   ui_framework: "XAML"
 17: 
 18: # ============================================================================
 19: # REQUIRED NUGET PACKAGES
 20: # ============================================================================
 21: packages:
 22:   mvvm:
 23:     - name: "CommunityToolkit.Mvvm"

 25:       purpose: "Source generators for MVVM (ObservableProperty, RelayCommand)"

 27:   cqrs:

 29:       version: "12.0+"
 30:       purpose: "Mediator pattern for CQRS architecture"
 31:       downloads: "607M+"

 33:   logging:
 34:     - name: "Serilog"

 36:       purpose: "Structured logging framework"
 37:       downloads: "2.3B+"
 38:     - name: "Serilog.Sinks.File"

 40:       purpose: "File sink for Serilog (rolling daily logs)"
 41:     - name: "Serilog.Extensions.Logging"

 43:       purpose: "Integration with Microsoft.Extensions.Logging"
 44: 
 45:   validation:
 46:     - name: "FluentValidation"
 47:       version: "11.8+"
 48:       purpose: "Declarative validation rules"
 49:       downloads: "741M+"
 50: 
 51:   csv:

 53:       version: "30.0+"
 54:       purpose: "Type-safe CSV export/import"
 55:       downloads: "34M+"
 56: 
 57:   navigation:
 58:     - name: "Uno.Extensions.Navigation.WinUI"
 59:       version: "4.0+"
 60:       purpose: "ViewModel-first navigation library"
 61:       recommended: true
 62: 
 63:   database:
 64:     - name: "MySqlConnector"
 65:       version: "2.3+"
 66:       purpose: "MySQL database connectivity"
 67:     - name: "Microsoft.Data.SqlClient"
 68:       version: "5.1+"
 69:       purpose: "SQL Server connectivity (READ ONLY for Infor Visual)"
 70: 
 71: # ============================================================================
 72: # ARCHITECTURAL PATTERNS
 73: # ============================================================================
 74: patterns:
 75:   primary:
 76:     - name: "MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel)"
 77:       enforcement: "strict"
 78:       description: "Separation of UI, presentation logic, and business logic"
 79: 
 80:     - name: "CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)"
 81:       enforcement: "required"
 82:       description: "Separate read (queries) from write (commands) operations"
 83: 
 84:     - name: "Repository Pattern (DAO)"
 85:       enforcement: "required"
 86:       description: "Instance-based Data Access Objects with structured results"
 87: 
 88:     - name: "Dependency Injection"
 89:       enforcement: "strict"
 90:       description: "Constructor injection only, no service locator"
 91: 
 92:   supporting:
 93:     - name: "Pipeline Behaviors"
 94:       scope: "global"
 95:       location: "Module_Core/Behaviors/"
 96:       description: "Cross-cutting concerns (logging, validation, audit)"
 97: 
 98:     - name: "Event Aggregator"
 99:       scope: "optional"
100:       description: "Loosely coupled module communication"
101: 
102: # ============================================================================
103: # NAMING CONVENTIONS
104: # ============================================================================
105: naming:
106:   modules:
107:     pattern: "Module_{Feature}/"
108:     example: "Module_Receiving/"
109:     case: "PascalCase"
110: 
111:   viewmodels:
112:     pattern: "ViewModel_{Module}_{Feature}"
113:     example: "ViewModel_Receiving_POEntry"
114:     modifiers: "partial class"
115:     inheritance: "ViewModel_Shared_Base"
116: 
117:   views:
118:     pattern: "View_{Module}_{Feature}"
119:     example: "View_Receiving_POEntry"
120:     file_xaml: "View_Receiving_POEntry.xaml"
121:     file_code: "View_Receiving_POEntry.xaml.cs"
122: 
123:   handlers:
124:     queries:
125:       pattern: "{Verb}{Entity}Query / {Verb}{Entity}Handler"
126:       example: "GetReceivingLineQuery / GetReceivingLineHandler"
127:       verbs: ["Get", "List", "Search", "Find", "Exists", "Count"]
128: 
129:     commands:
130:       pattern: "{Verb}{Entity}Command / {Verb}{Entity}Handler"
131:       example: "InsertReceivingLineCommand / InsertReceivingLineHandler"
132:       verbs: ["Insert", "Update", "Delete", "Archive", "Restore", "Activate"]
133: 
134:   validators:
135:     pattern: "{CommandName}Validator"
136:     example: "InsertReceivingLineValidator"
137:     inheritance: "AbstractValidator<T>"
138: 
139:   daos:
140:     pattern: "Dao_{EntityName}"
141:     example: "Dao_ReceivingLine"
142:     style: "instance-based (NOT static)"
143: 
144:   models:
145:     pattern: "Model_{EntityName}"
146:     example: "Model_ReceivingLine"
147: 
148:   services:
149:     interface: "IService_{Purpose}"
150:     implementation: "Service_{Purpose}"
151:     example: "IService_ErrorHandler / Service_ErrorHandler"
152: 
153:   methods:
154:     async: "must end with 'Async' suffix"
155:     example: "LoadDataAsync(), SaveAsync(), DeleteAsync()"
156: 
157: # ============================================================================
158: # CODE QUALITY STANDARDS
159: # ============================================================================
160: code_quality:
161:   accessibility:
162:     rule: "Explicit accessibility modifiers required"
163:     example: "public, private, protected, internal"
164: 
165:   braces:
166:     rule: "Required for all control flow statements"
167:     enforcement: "strict"
168: 
169:   async:
170:     rule: "All async methods must end with 'Async' suffix"
171:     enforcement: "strict"
172: 
173:   documentation:
174:     rule: "XML documentation required for public APIs"
175:     format: "/// <summary>...</summary>"
176: 
177:   binding:
178:     xaml: "x:Bind (compile-time) required"
179:     forbidden: "Binding (runtime)"
180: 
181: # ============================================================================
182: # PERFORMANCE TARGETS
183: # ============================================================================
184: performance:
185:   validation:
186:     target: "< 10ms"
187:     measured_at: "ValidationBehavior pipeline"
188: 
189:   dao_query:
190:     target: "< 50ms"
191:     measured_at: "DAO stored procedure execution"
192: 
193:   handler_execution:
194:     target: "< 100ms"
195:     measured_at: "Handler complete lifecycle"
196: 
197:   end_to_end:
198:     target: "< 200ms"
199:     measured_at: "ViewModel request to response"
200: 
201:   view_load:
202:     target: "< 200ms"
203:     measured_at: "View initialization and first render"
204: 
205: # ============================================================================
206: # DATABASE CONSTRAINTS
207: # ============================================================================
208: database:
209:   mysql:
210:     connection_string_source: "Helper_Database_Variables.GetConnectionString()"
211:     operations: "READ/WRITE"
212:     stored_procedures: "required for all operations"
213:     raw_sql: "forbidden in C# code"
214: 
215:   sql_server_infor_visual:
216:     server: "VISUAL"
217:     databases:
218:       production: "MTMFG"
219:       playground: "MTMFGPLAY"
220:     connection_string: "ApplicationIntent=ReadOnly required"
221:     operations: "READ ONLY"
222:     forbidden: ["INSERT", "UPDATE", "DELETE"]
223: 
224:   audit_columns:
225:     required: ["CreatedBy", "CreatedDate", "ModifiedBy", "ModifiedDate"]
226:     type: "string (username), DateTime (UTC)"
227: 
228: # ============================================================================
229: # DEPENDENCY INJECTION RULES
230: # ============================================================================
231: dependency_injection:
232:   lifetimes:
233:     singleton:
234:       use_for: ["Stateless services", "Thread-safe services"]
235:       examples:
236:         [
237:           "IService_ErrorHandler",
238:           "ILogger",
239:           "DAOs",
240:           "Global Pipeline Behaviors",
241:         ]
242:       registration: "services.AddSingleton<IService, Service>()"
243: 
244:     transient:
245:       use_for: ["Stateful services", "Per-operation data"]
246:       examples: ["ViewModels", "Handlers", "Validators"]
247:       registration: "services.AddTransient<ViewModel>()"
248: 
249:     scoped:
250:       use_for: "Not applicable to WinUI desktop apps"
251:       note: "Scoped lifetime is for web applications only"
252: 
253:   anti_patterns:
254:     captive_dependency:
255:       rule: "Never inject Transient into Singleton"
256:       reason: "Causes stale data and memory leaks"
257: 
258: # ============================================================================
259: # MODULE STRUCTURE
260: # ============================================================================
261: module_structure:
262:   canonical_folders:
263:     - name: "Data/"
264:       purpose: "Instance-based DAOs for database operations"
265: 
266:     - name: "Models/"
267:       purpose: "Domain entities and DTOs"
268: 
269:     - name: "Handlers/"
270:       purpose: "CQRS command/query handlers"
271:       subfolders: ["Queries/", "Commands/"]
272: 
273:     - name: "Validators/"
274:       purpose: "FluentValidation validators for commands"
275: 
276:     - name: "ViewModels/"
277:       purpose: "Presentation logic (partial classes)"
278: 
279:     - name: "Views/"
280:       purpose: "XAML UI files"
281: 
282:     - name: "Services/"
283:       purpose: "Feature-specific services (minimal, optional)"
284: 
285:     - name: "Defaults/"
286:       purpose: "Configuration and constants"
287: 
288:     - name: "Preparation/"
289:       purpose: "Planning artifacts and documentation"
290: 
291:   forbidden_folders:
292:     - name: "Behaviors/"
293:       reason: "Pipeline behaviors are GLOBAL in Module_Core only"
294: 
295: # ============================================================================
296: # MODULE INDEPENDENCE CRITERIA
297: # ============================================================================
298: module_independence:
299:   allowed_dependencies:
300:     - "Module_Core (generic infrastructure only)"
301:     - "External NuGet packages"
302: 
303:   forbidden_dependencies:
304:     - "Other Module_{Feature} folders"
305:     - "Direct references to feature-specific code in other modules"
306: 
307:   allowed_core_services:
308:     - "IService_ErrorHandler"
309:     - "IService_Window"
310:     - "IService_Dispatcher"
311:     - "Helper_Database_Variables"
312:     - "Helper_Database_StoredProcedure"
313:     - "Global Pipeline Behaviors (LoggingBehavior, ValidationBehavior, AuditBehavior)"
314:     - "ViewModel_Shared_Base"
315:     - "Model_Dao_Result<T>"
316: 
317:   communication:
318:     method: "Event Aggregator (optional)"
319:     location: "Module_Core"
320:     coupling: "loose (publisher doesn't know subscribers)"
321: 
322: # ============================================================================
323: # TESTING REQUIREMENTS
324: # ============================================================================
325: testing:
326:   framework: "xUnit"
327:   assertions: "FluentAssertions"
328:   coverage_target: "80%+"
329: 
330:   unit_tests:
331:     - "ViewModels with mocked IMediator"
332:     - "Handlers with mocked DAOs"
333:     - "Validators with test data"
334: 
335:   integration_tests:
336:     - "DAOs against test database"
337:     - "End-to-end workflow scenarios"
338: 
339: # ============================================================================
340: # DOCUMENTATION REQUIREMENTS
341: # ============================================================================
342: documentation:
343:   diagrams:
344:     format: "PlantUML"
345:     forbidden: "ASCII art"
346: 
347:   required_files:
348:     module_root:
349:       - "README.md (module overview)"
350:       - "ARCHITECTURE.md (design decisions)"
351:       - "DATA_MODEL.md (PlantUML ERD)"
352:       - "WORKFLOWS.md (PlantUML state diagrams)"
353:       - "CODE_REVIEW_CHECKLIST.md (constitutional compliance)"
354: 
355:     preparation:
356:       - "03_Clarification_Questions.md"
357:       - "04_Implementation_Order.md"
358:       - "05_Task_Checklist.md"
359:       - "06_Schematic_File.md"
360:       - "07_Research_Archive.md"
361: 
362: # ============================================================================
363: # ERROR HANDLING STRATEGY
364: # ============================================================================
365: error_handling:
366:   daos:
367:     rule: "NEVER throw exceptions"
368:     return: "Model_Dao_Result.Failure(errorMessage)"
369: 
370:   handlers:
371:     rule: "Wrap in try-catch"
372:     catch: ["DbException", "ValidationException", "Exception"]
373:     return: "Model_Dao_Result.Failure(userFriendlyMessage)"
374:     log: "Full exception with context"
375: 
376:   viewmodels:
377:     rule: "Use IService_ErrorHandler for user-facing errors"
378:     method: "_errorHandler.ShowUserError(message, title, source)"
379: 
380: # ============================================================================
381: # LOGGING STANDARDS
382: # ============================================================================
383: logging:
384:   format: "Structured logging with semantic properties"
385: 
386:   correct:
387:     example: '_logger.LogInformation("User {UserId} performed {Action}", userId, action)'
388: 
389:   incorrect:
390:     example: '_logger.LogInformation("User " + userId + " performed " + action)'
391: 
392:   enrichers:
393:     - "Machine name"
394:     - "Thread ID"
395:     - "Application name"
396:     - "Module name"
397:     - "Environment (Dev/Staging/Production)"
398: 
399:   output:
400:     file: "logs/app-.txt"
401:     rolling: "daily"
402:     retention: "30 days"
403: 
404: # ============================================================================
405: # CONSTITUTIONAL CONSTRAINTS (NON-NEGOTIABLE)
406: # ============================================================================
407: constitutional:
408:   mvvm:
409:     - "ViewModels SHALL NOT directly call DAOs"
410:     - "ViewModels SHALL NOT access database helpers"
411:     - "All data access MUST flow through Mediator layer"
412:     - "All ViewModels MUST be partial classes"
413:     - "All data binding MUST use x:Bind (compile-time)"

415:   database:

417:     - "All DAOs MUST return Model_Dao_Result or Model_Dao_Result<T>"
418:     - "DAOs MUST be instance-based (NOT static)"
419:     - "SQL Server (Infor Visual) is READ ONLY"
420: 
421:   dependency_injection:
422:     - "All services MUST be registered in App.xaml.cs"
423:     - "Constructor injection REQUIRED"
424:     - "Service locator pattern is FORBIDDEN"
425: 
426:   error_handling:
427:     - "Use centralized IService_ErrorHandler for user errors"
428:     - "Use structured logging for diagnostics"
429:     - "DAOs MUST NOT throw exceptions"
430: 
431:   code_quality:
432:     - "Explicit accessibility modifiers required"
433:     - "Braces required for all control flow"
434:     - "Async methods MUST end with 'Async'"
435:     - "XML documentation required for public APIs"
436: 
437: # ============================================================================
438: # REFERENCES
439: # ============================================================================
440: references:
441:   official_docs:
442:     - name: "MediatR Wiki"
443:       url: "https://github.com/jbogard/MediatR/wiki"
444: 
445:     - name: "Serilog Documentation"
446:       url: "https://serilog.net"
447: 
448:     - name: "FluentValidation Documentation"

 5: using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging;
 6: 
 7: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Behaviors
 8: {
 9:     /// <summary>
10:     /// Global pipeline behavior that adds audit context to all requests.
11:     /// Automatically applied to ALL handlers in ALL modules.
12:     /// Logs user context, machine name, and timestamp for compliance and troubleshooting.
13:     /// </summary>
14:     /// <typeparam name="TRequest">The request type.</typeparam>
15:     /// <typeparam name="TResponse">The response type.</typeparam>
16:     public class AuditBehavior<TRequest, TResponse> : IPipelineBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>
17:         where TRequest : IRequest<TResponse>
18:     {
19:         private readonly ILogger<AuditBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>> _logger;
20: 
21:         public AuditBehavior(ILogger<AuditBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>> logger)
22:         {
23:             _logger = logger;
24:         }
25: 
26:         public async Task<TResponse> Handle(
27:             TRequest request,
28:             RequestHandlerDelegate<TResponse> next,
29:             CancellationToken cancellationToken)
30:         {
31:             var requestName = typeof(TRequest).Name;
32: 
33:             // Capture audit context
34:             var userId = Environment.UserName; // TODO: Replace with authenticated user from IService_Authentication
35:             var timestamp = DateTime.UtcNow;
36:             var machineName = Environment.MachineName;
37: 
38:             _logger.LogInformation(
39:                 "Audit: User {UserId} executing {RequestName} at {Timestamp} from {MachineName}",
40:                 userId,
41:                 requestName,

44: 
45:             // Proceed to next behavior or handler
46:             return await next();
47:         }
48:     }

## File: Module_Core/Behaviors/LoggingBehavior.cs
````csharp
 1: using System;
 2: using System.Diagnostics;
 3: using System.Threading;
 4: using System.Threading.Tasks;
 5: using MediatR;
 6: using Microsoft.Extensions.Logging;
 7: 
 8: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Behaviors
 9: {
10:     /// <summary>
11:     /// Global pipeline behavior that logs all MediatR requests.
12:     /// Automatically applied to ALL handlers in ALL modules.
13:     /// </summary>
14:     /// <typeparam name="TRequest">The request type.</typeparam>
15:     /// <typeparam name="TResponse">The response type.</typeparam>
16:     public class LoggingBehavior<TRequest, TResponse> : IPipelineBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>
17:         where TRequest : IRequest<TResponse>
18:     {
19:         private readonly ILogger<LoggingBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>> _logger;
20: 
21:         public LoggingBehavior(ILogger<LoggingBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>> logger)
22:         {
23:             _logger = logger;
24:         }
25: 
26:         public async Task<TResponse> Handle(
27:             TRequest request,
28:             RequestHandlerDelegate<TResponse> next,
29:             CancellationToken cancellationToken)
30:         {
31:             var requestName = typeof(TRequest).Name;
32:             var requestGuid = Guid.NewGuid().ToString();
33: 
34:             _logger.LogInformation(
35:                 "[{RequestGuid}] Handling {RequestName}",
36:                 requestGuid,
37:                 requestName);
38: 
39:             var stopwatch = Stopwatch.StartNew();
40: 
41:             try
42:             {
43:                 var response = await next();
44: 
45:                 stopwatch.Stop();
46: 
47:                 _logger.LogInformation(
48:                     "[{RequestGuid}] Handled {RequestName} in {ElapsedMilliseconds}ms",
49:                     requestGuid,
50:                     requestName,
51:                     stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds);
52: 
53:                 return response;
54:             }
55:             catch (Exception ex)
56:             {
57:                 stopwatch.Stop();
58: 
59:                 _logger.LogError(
60:                     ex,
61:                     "[{RequestGuid}] Error handling {RequestName} after {ElapsedMilliseconds}ms: {ErrorMessage}",
62:                     requestGuid,
63:                     requestName,
64:                     stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds,
65:                     ex.Message);
66: 
67:                 throw;
68:             }
69:         }
70:     }
71: }
````

## File: Module_Core/Behaviors/ValidationBehavior.cs
````csharp
 1: using System;
 2: using System.Collections.Generic;
 3: using System.Linq;
 4: using System.Threading;
 5: using System.Threading.Tasks;
 6: using FluentValidation;
 7: using MediatR;
 8: 
 9: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Behaviors
10: {
11:     /// <summary>
12:     /// Global pipeline behavior that validates commands using FluentValidation.
13:     /// Automatically applied to ALL commands in ALL modules.
14:     /// Validation occurs BEFORE the handler executes.
15:     /// </summary>
16:     /// <typeparam name="TRequest">The request type.</typeparam>
17:     /// <typeparam name="TResponse">The response type.</typeparam>
18:     public class ValidationBehavior<TRequest, TResponse> : IPipelineBehavior<TRequest, TResponse>
19:         where TRequest : IRequest<TResponse>
20:     {
21:         private readonly IEnumerable<IValidator<TRequest>> _validators;
22: 
23:         public ValidationBehavior(IEnumerable<IValidator<TRequest>> validators)
24:         {
25:             _validators = validators;
26:         }
27: 
28:         public async Task<TResponse> Handle(
29:             TRequest request,
30:             RequestHandlerDelegate<TResponse> next,
31:             CancellationToken cancellationToken)
32:         {
33:             // If no validators registered for this request type, skip validation
34:             if (!_validators.Any())
35:             {
36:                 return await next();
37:             }
38: 
39:             var context = new ValidationContext<TRequest>(request);
40: 
41:             // Run all validators in parallel
42:             var validationResults = await Task.WhenAll(
43:                 _validators.Select(v => v.ValidateAsync(context, cancellationToken)));
44: 
45:             // Collect all validation failures
46:             var failures = validationResults
47:                 .SelectMany(r => r.Errors)
48:                 .Where(f => f != null)
49:                 .ToList();
50: 
51:             // If any validation failures, throw ValidationException (short-circuits handler execution)
52:             if (failures.Any())
53:             {
54:                 throw new ValidationException(failures);
55:             }
56: 
57:             // Validation passed, proceed to handler
58:             return await next();
59:         }
60:     }
61: }
````

## File: Module_Core/Converters/Converter_DecimalToInt.cs
````csharp
 1: using Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Data;
 2: using System;
 3: 
 4: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Converters
 5: {
 6:     /// <summary>
 7:     /// Converts decimal values to integer (whole number) for display, removing decimal places.
 8:     /// </summary>
 9:     public class Converter_DecimalToInt : IValueConverter
10:     {
11:         public object Convert(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)
12:         {
13:             if (value is decimal decimalValue)
14:             {
15:                 return ((int)decimalValue).ToString("N0");
16:             }
17:             if (value is double doubleValue)
18:             {
19:                 return ((int)doubleValue).ToString("N0");
20:             }
21:             if (value is float floatValue)
22:             {
23:                 return ((int)floatValue).ToString("N0");
24:             }
25:             return value?.ToString() ?? string.Empty;
26:         }
27: 
28:         public object ConvertBack(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)
29:         {
30:             if (value is string strValue && decimal.TryParse(strValue, out decimal result))
31:             {
32:                 return result;
33:             }
34:             return 0m;
35:         }
36:     }
37: }
````

## File: Module_Core/Converters/Converter_EnumToVisibility.cs
````csharp
 1: using Microsoft.UI.Xaml;
 2: using Microsoft.UI.Xaml.Data;
 3: using System;
 4: 
 5: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Converters;
 6: 
 7: /// <summary>
 8: /// Converts enum value to Visibility based on parameter match
 9: /// </summary>
10: public class Converter_EnumToVisibility : IValueConverter
11: {
12:     public object Convert(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)
13:     {
14:         if (value == null || parameter == null)
15:         {
16:             return Visibility.Collapsed;
17:         }
18: 
19:         var enumValue = value.ToString();
20:         var targetValue = parameter.ToString();
21: 
22:         return string.Equals(enumValue, targetValue, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase)
23:             ? Visibility.Visible
24:             : Visibility.Collapsed;
25:     }
26: 
27:     public object ConvertBack(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)

 5: namespace MTM_Receiving_Application.Module_Core.Converters
 6: {
 7:     /// <summary>
 8:     /// Converts an integer value to Visibility
 9:     /// - If ConverterParameter is an integer string (e.g., "1", "2"), compares value == parameter
10:     /// - If ConverterParameter is "Inverse", shows when value == 0
11:     /// - If no parameter, shows when value > 0
12:     /// </summary>
13:     public class Converter_IntToVisibility : IValueConverter
14:     {
15:         public object Convert(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)
16:         {
17:             if (value == null)
18:                 return Visibility.Collapsed;
19: 
20:             int intValue = value is int i ? i : 0;
21:             bool isVisible;
22: 
23:             // Handle different parameter types
24:             if (parameter is string paramStr)
25:             {
26:                 // Check for "Inverse" parameter (legacy behavior: show when count is 0)
27:                 if (paramStr.Equals("Inverse", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase))
28:                 {
29:                     isVisible = intValue == 0;
30:                 }
31:                 // Check for numeric parameter (e.g., "1", "2", "3" for step matching)
32:                 else if (int.TryParse(paramStr, out int paramInt))
33:                 {
34:                     isVisible = intValue == paramInt;
35:                 }
36:                 else
37:                 {
38:                     // Fallback for unknown string parameters
39:                     isVisible = intValue > 0;
40:                 }
41:             }
42:             else if (parameter is int paramIntDirect)
43:             {
44:                 // Direct integer parameter comparison
45:                 isVisible = intValue == paramIntDirect;
46:             }
47:             else
48:             {
49:                 // No parameter: show if value > 0 (legacy behavior)
50:                 isVisible = intValue > 0;
51:             }
52: 
53:             return isVisible ? Visibility.Visible : Visibility.Collapsed;
54:         }
55: 
56:         public object ConvertBack(object? value, Type targetType, object? parameter, string language)
57:         {
58:             throw new NotImplementedException();
59:         }
60:     }
61: }

 20:     private static readonly int[] RetryDelaysMs = { 100, 200, 400 };

 22:     /// <summary>

 24:     /// </summary>

 29:         string procedureName,

 33:         var result = new Model_Dao_Result();
 34:         var stopwatch = Stopwatch.StartNew();
 35:         int attempt = 0;
 36: 
 37:         while (attempt < MaxRetries)
 38:         {
 39:             attempt++;
 40: 
 41:             try
 42:             {
 43:                 await using var connection = new MySqlConnection(connectionString);
 44:                 await connection.OpenAsync();
 45: 
 46:                 await using var command = new MySqlCommand(procedureName, connection)
 47:                 {
 48:                     CommandType = CommandType.StoredProcedure
 49:                 };
 50: 
 51:                 if (parameters != null)
 52:                 {
 53:                     command.Parameters.AddRange(parameters);
 54:                 }
 55: 
 56:                 var affectedRows = await command.ExecuteNonQueryAsync();
 57: 
 58:                 // Handle output parameters if any
 59:                 foreach (var param in command.Parameters)
 60:                 {
 61:                     if (param is MySqlParameter p && (p.Direction == ParameterDirection.Output || p.Direction == ParameterDirection.InputOutput))
 62:                     {
 63:                         // You might want to capture output values here if needed
 64:                         // For now, we just ensure the command executes
 65:                     }
 66:                 }
 67: 
 68:                 stopwatch.Stop();
 69:                 result.Success = true;
 70:                 result.AffectedRows = affectedRows;
 71:                 result.ExecutionTimeMs = stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds;
 72:                 return result;
 73:             }
 74:             catch (MySqlException ex) when (IsTransientError(ex) && attempt < MaxRetries)
 75:             {
 76:                 await Task.Delay(RetryDelaysMs[attempt - 1]);
 77:                 continue;
 78:             }
 79:             catch (Exception ex)
 80:             {
 81:                 stopwatch.Stop();
 82:                 return Model_Dao_Result_Factory.Failure($"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed: {ex.Message}", ex);
 83:             }
 84:         }
 85: 
 86:         stopwatch.Stop();
 87:         return Model_Dao_Result_Factory.Failure($"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed after {MaxRetries} attempts");
 88:     }

100: 
101:         foreach (var param in parameters)

103:             if (param.Value == null && param.Direction == ParameterDirection.Input)

106:                 return false;
107:             }
108:         }
109:         return true;

135:                 await using var connection = new MySqlConnection(connectionString);
136:                 await connection.OpenAsync();
137: 
138:                 await using var command = new MySqlCommand(procedureName, connection)
139:                 {
140:                     CommandType = CommandType.StoredProcedure
141:                 };
142: 
143:                 AddParameters(command, parameters);

333:                 return result;
334:             }
335:             catch (MySqlException ex) when (IsTransientError(ex) && attempt < MaxRetries)
336:             {
337:                 await Task.Delay(RetryDelaysMs[attempt - 1]);
338:                 continue;
339:             }
340:             catch (Exception ex)
341:             {
342:                 stopwatch.Stop();
343:                 System.Diagnostics.Debug.WriteLine($"[DB] ERROR in ExecuteListAsync: {procedureName}");
344:                 System.Diagnostics.Debug.WriteLine($"[DB] Error Type: {ex.GetType().Name}");
345:                 System.Diagnostics.Debug.WriteLine($"[DB] Error Message: {ex.Message}");
346:                 if (ex is MySqlException sqlEx)
347:                 {
348:                     System.Diagnostics.Debug.WriteLine($"[DB] MySQL Error Code: {sqlEx.Number}");
349:                     System.Diagnostics.Debug.WriteLine($"[DB] SQL State: {sqlEx.SqlState}");
350:                 }
351:                 return Model_Dao_Result_Factory.Failure<List<T>>($"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed: {ex.Message}", ex);
352:             }
353:         }
354: 
355:         stopwatch.Stop();
356:         return Model_Dao_Result_Factory.Failure<List<T>>($"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed after {MaxRetries} attempts");
357:     }

359:     /// <summary>
360:     /// Executes a stored procedure that returns a DataTable (SELECT)
361:     /// </summary>
362:     /// <param name="connectionString"></param>
363:     /// <param name="procedureName"></param>
364:     /// <param name="parameters"></param>
365:     public static async Task<Model_Dao_Result<DataTable>> ExecuteDataTableAsync(
366:         string connectionString,
367:         string procedureName,
368:         Dictionary<string, object>? parameters = null)
369:     {
370:         var result = new Model_Dao_Result<DataTable>();
371:         var stopwatch = Stopwatch.StartNew();
372:         int attempt = 0;
373: 
374:         while (attempt < MaxRetries)
375:         {
376:             attempt++;
377: 
378:             try
379:             {
380:                 await using var connection = new MySqlConnection(connectionString);
381:                 await connection.OpenAsync();
382: 
383:                 await using var command = new MySqlCommand(procedureName, connection)
384:                 {
385:                     CommandType = CommandType.StoredProcedure
386:                 };
387: 
388:                 AddParameters(command, parameters);
389: 
390:                 await using var reader = await command.ExecuteReaderAsync();
391:                 var dataTable = new DataTable();
392:                 dataTable.Load(reader);
393: 
394:                 stopwatch.Stop();
395:                 result.Success = true;
396:                 result.Data = dataTable;
397:                 result.AffectedRows = dataTable.Rows.Count;
398:                 result.ExecutionTimeMs = stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds;
399:                 return result;
400:             }
401:             catch (MySqlException ex) when (IsTransientError(ex) && attempt < MaxRetries)
402:             {
403:                 await Task.Delay(RetryDelaysMs[attempt - 1]);
404:                 continue;
405:             }
406:             catch (Exception ex)
407:             {
408:                 stopwatch.Stop();
409:                 result.Success = false;
410:                 result.ErrorMessage = $"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed: {ex.Message}";
411:                 result.Severity = Enum_ErrorSeverity.Error;
412:                 result.ExecutionTimeMs = stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds;
413:                 result.Exception = ex;
414:                 return result;
415:             }
416:         }
417: 
418:         stopwatch.Stop();
419:         result.Success = false;
420:         result.ErrorMessage = $"Stored procedure '{procedureName}' failed after {MaxRetries} attempts";
421:         result.Severity = Enum_ErrorSeverity.Critical;
422:         result.ExecutionTimeMs = stopwatch.ElapsedMilliseconds;
423:         return result;
424:     }
